title: How does a parent help a teenager take responsibility for his actions and stop blaming other people or circumstances for his mistakes? - Quora

response.answer_text: Clearly explaining "if/then" situations might help. You’ll have to constantly point out that if he does X, then Y or Z are the possible outcomes. There’s no way to know which until it happens. But, if he chooses to do X, he can’t be surprised about either outcome, and no one else can take the credit or the blame. It’s all his. I think I might also point out that when the outcome of his decisions is good, why does he take credit instead of giving it to someone else? The outcome, positive or negative, doesn’t change who’s responsible for making the decision. All of it, good or bad, falls on the decision maker. Maybe he’s been sharply criticized when things turn out badly, or has been told "I told you so", so rejects assuming responsibility to avoid a lecture or being chastised. When faced with a decision, point out the possible outcomes, or have him name them, but make no recriminations if things don’t turn out well. Help him think it through, then be quiet about the matter. The only thing I used to say to my son was, "Well, that’s a shame; but, have you learned anything? That’s what’s important." I didn’t rush to remedy the situation for him, either. His decision - his consequence or reward. He’s the one who ends up enjoying it or suffering from it. We have to teach personal responsibility. It doesn’t happen in a vacuum.

I'm glad I'm not the only parent going through this… I don't remember my older kids doing this but maybe its been so long ago that I've forgotten. Right now I'm still trying to live through it…. I listen to a lot of podcast but haven't come across one solely in this area yet. I'm sure there is one out there at least one…. Lol Anyway, what I'm doing is simply , saying that's sad or whatever fits…… . and saying but what is your part? What can we work on to change next time? If he doesnt know I ask questions such as did you do _______. I always ask what is it you could do next time to not repeat the same mistake/ thing/ circumstances etc… I also remind him that ever since Adam and Eve people have been pointing fingers and blame elsewhere - even if there is truth to it being someone else who started it… We must realize we had a choice and for that we have to take responsibility …for we won't ever get to a better place if we don't seek to know our part and make a better choice next time. If possible I also share a time when I messed up and blamed things on someone else and what my outcome was (ie. I was 2 years older than my brother and he wanted to go hang out with our cousins and I had a friend who lived close- so I walked with him to hang out with my friend, under the pretense that he'd come back for me so we could be back at granny's before mom got home from work… well as it started getting later and the sunset was approaching- I said I needed to go and walked through the woods looking for the clubhouse where the cousins were but was afraid I'd get lost- so I decided to go home without him… guess what?? He went home without me…. I got a spanking I'd never forget- but I never did that again!). We both did wrong and both had a part but only one got caught and in trouble, for I did make a choice to go and hang out with a friend and listen to music in her room… Besides if we blamed the other they could go pick out a switch for our spanking.

Being the parent is not to waver. If you want them to be responsible, set expectations and do not back down. If you do it once they will work towards getting you, needling you until you give in again. Establish House Rules and Conduct Mis-Step Consequences. Allow them to participate in setting binding consequences. To your surprise they set pretty strict, go for it, assure they are binding.Share with them the very lean list of parental requirements the law holds us accountable to providing to our children, that are basic with no fluff or nice to haves. Pointing out how much more you have given or want to give.Require them to make their bed every morning, which means you must start your day with this consistency as well if you want it in your children.Point out privileges they now enjoy, but are limited to age 18 if they choose to disrespect their home or more importantly you. The pleasures include a car, clothing beyond basics that may not be fashionable, eating out… etc.Be consistent in your own life to.

'taking responsibility' is garbage when it requires something like a parent/person wanting the other to say a thing is their fault etc. Point out the things that caused the problem, do it carefully and without blame, then ask what the kid could have realistically done differently to avoid the problem. Make it clear that the results aren't always going to be ideal, but that specific situations could have had better results. Ask for the *little* changes that could have achieved results that weren't the best, but could have still been realistically at least a bit better than whatever actually happened. In particular, aim for things where the immediate result would have at least been a step closer to the desired goal, rather than the flawed choice that was made which either stopped them in their tracks or pushed them further away from the goal.

Make him pay for his own mistakes and wait some years for him to grow up. Teens are capable of cooking food, doing laundry, setting an alarm clock to wake up in the morning, and writing down due dates for assignments. Don’t clean his area or do his laundry. If he has only nasty clothes to wear because he won’t do his own laundry, let him face the public humiliation. If he misses the bus to school, don’t give him a ride, make him walk or pay for an Uber. If he forgets his lunch, let him go hungry. It won’t hurt him. He will continue trying to play the blame game. Don’t tolerate it. Tell him that in a couple years he will be a grown adult who can get married, vote, join the military, get tattoos, and be prosecuted as an adult if he breaks the law. Starting today, he is being treated like an adult, which means he is responsible for taking care of himself.

Firstly you need a crisis point. Children - teens always respond better after they have just broken something and are feeling remorseful enough to sit and listen. If it was important I used to try and construct a time line in my mind or on paper where you can sit with the child- teen and explain what went wrong, how it went wrong , and what lead up to the event. Once they can see what was the cause then you can start explaining the alternative steps that could have been taken at various stages to alter the outcome. All good so far but pretty boring ok use humour, teens response well to embarrassment so I will not call them stupid but I will say you did something stupid I will also try and do it in a funny way so I get the message across but the humour softens the message. So I might sigh and say listen there’s a small town just up road I will see if I can get you in there , they are still looking for a new village idiot.

This should have been taught from the time he could talk. It’s going to be challenging bc you’re trying this in his teen years. I’d like to recommend an excellent book “The Kazdin Method” by Alan Kazdin, MD. His methods really do work. No shouting, arguing, defiance and it works with toddlers to teens. Honest.

By example. If he is learning blaming somewhere else, point out to him that there are always choices. Be accountable, ( do what you say you'll do or take consequences) , don't explain, just accept when you're wrong. Hell feel better about himself.
By being a good role model and owning their own mistakes and apologizing. a child needs to be brought up from young on to accept the consequences for their choices.
Teaching your teenager that it’s ok to make mistakes. Help him see his mistakes as opportunities for growth and for learning.
Let them to take ALL of the consequences.
